 I. COUNTRY BACKGROUND AND THE 1998 FLOODS A. Bangladesh: A Land of Rivers 1.1 Bangladesh is a land of rivers. The intricate network of over 200 large and small rivers annually discharges some 175 billion cubic meters of water and about 2.4 billion tons of sediment into the Bay of Bengal. The country also receives between 1,000 to 5,000 mm of rain annually, about 80 percent during the monsoon season between June and September. 1.2 Massive rainfall and peak season flows through the Ganges-Brahmaputra-Meghna river system cause seasonal flooding in Bangladesh, particularly when the two phenomena peak together. The crops vulnerable to flood damage are aus rice (harvested in June-July), aman rice (about 50 percent of total rice production, and harvested in November-December), boro rice (harvested in March-April), jute, sugarcane, and summer vegetables. In an average year, 35 percent of the net cultivated area is subjected to shallow flooding (30-90 cm), 16 percent to moderate flooding (90-180 cm), and 12 percent to deep flooding (more than 180 cm). The people and economy of Bangladesh have adapted over generations to this type of flooding. However, when flood intensity sharply exceeds these averages, as has recently happened every 10- 15 years, there is enormous loss of life, livelihoods, property, and crops. 1.3 Both before and after its independence, Bangladesh has made various, partial attempts to manage its vast water resources. Bangladesh most recently suffered from major flooding in 1954, 1955, 1974, 1987, and 1988. The 1988 floods were short-lived but catastrophic because of the rapidity with which the flood waters rose. The 1987 and 1988 floods led Bangladesh, with assistance from bilateral and multilateral donors, to undertake more than 20 joint studies on flood mitigation and control, now collectively known as the Flood Action Plan (FAP)! The main components of the FAP included several regional and urban planning studies, project-specific studies, and special programs on flood forecasting, early warning, and flood preparedness. Implementation of some of the FAP projects started in 1990 to minimise damage to agricultural production through better .management of flood waters, and to meet some of the needs for fisheries, navigation, and public health. The FAP analyses and projects have attracted their share of criticism, in particular relating to the technical solutions proposed, the co-ordination of different components, the early focus on flood control alone (later broadened to integrate water management), the lack of local participation, and the extent and nature of dissemination. In spite of their shortcomings, the FAP studies and projects have been useful in stressing the importance, when dealing with floods, of the complete hydrological cycle and of developing an integrated management plan that covers not only flooding but also drainage, irrigation, navigation, the environment, socio-economic factors, and the importance of beneficiary participation at all stages of project development. At the conclusion of the FAP, the government produced its first Water and Flood Management Strategy (September 1995), out of which has grown the National Water Policy and the National Water Management Plan, under preparation with assistance from IDA. It will be important to assess prior work on flood mitigation done under the FAP and the subsequent development of water management in Bangladesh once the full impact of the 1998 floods becomes clearer. 'For a summary, see Water Resources Management in Bangladesh: Steps Towards a New National Water Plan, Report No. 17663-BD, March 15, 1998, The World Bank.
 2 B. The 1998 Floods 1.4 The unprecedented flooding in 1998, the worst in living memory, is linked to the three main rivers-the Ganges, the Brahmaputra and the Meghna. Flows from the first two come from snowmelt in the Himalayas and rainfall, while the Meghna is primarily a rain-fed river. Each of these rivers usually peaks at different times of the year. However, when the peaks synchronise, as they did in 1988 and again in 1998, there is major flooding as several flood waves pass through the country. Unlike 1988, the 1998 floods were not only severe but also persisted for five times as long. The flood situation started to deteriorate in the middle of July 1998 due to heavy rainfall in the entire catchment area of the Ganges-Brahmaputra-Meghna system. Precipitation was 40 percent higher than normal in July, and 35 per cent higher in August. In addition, above normal snowfall in the Himalayas followed by a warm July substantially increased snowmelt. As a result, the Brahmaputra peaked thrice during July and August, and remained well above danger levels until the third week of September. The Ganges peaked in early August, matching the last flood wave through the Brahmaputra. The Meghna crossed the danger level in mid-July and remained there until the third week of September. Finally, sea levels in the Bay of Bengal were apparently higher during this period, further inhibiting drainage from the delta. The confluence of these events appears to have resulted in the unprecedented 1998 floods. C. International Response to the 1998 Floods 1.5 The international community's response to the floods has been swift. The Government issued an international appeal on August 26, 1998 requesting US$113 million for immediate relief and US$461 million for rehabilitation, including approximately US$250 million in additional food aid. The Government also requested emergency assistance from the Bank and the IMF. 1.6 In response to Government's appeal, the United Nations immediately fielded a damage assessment mission, led by the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, and issued a flash appeal for support. A technical working group on food requirements was established by the World Food Program (WFP). As an immediate response to the Government's request, the United Nations International Children's Emergency Fund, United Nations Development Program, World Health Organization, WFP, and United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reprogrammed their activities and obtained fresh commitments, enabling them to provide emergency supplies of medicines and other relief items. From the Local Consultative Group of donors in Dhaka, sub- groups on infrastructure, health, education, agriculture, water supply, and sanitation convened emergency meetings to co-ordinate their activities. By the end of September some US$145 million had been pledged by the international community in cash, kind, and food aid. An agreement with the IMF has been reached that will allow Bangladesh to access 25 percent of its quota, or approximately US$135 million, under the IMF's Emergency Finance Facility. The Asian Development Bank is planning a new, multi-sector Flood Rehabilitation Assistance Project that is expected to provide US$103 million, in addition to reprogramming some of its existing projects. Emergency Assistance and the Government's Adjustment Measures 2.9 Emergency Assistance: In parallel with the proposed IDA support for financing critical imports, the Government has successfully negotiated an agreement with the IMF for emergency balance of payments assistance (up to the ceiling of 25 percent of quota, SDR 98.1 million,
 7 US$135 million equivalent). The IMF's emergency assistance will support the Government's adjustment measures designed to maintain macroeconomic stability in the face of the 1998 floods. 2.10 Adjustment Measures: The Government has undertaken a series of macroeconomic steps designed to reduce pressure on the balance of payments and the overall budget deficit. The taka was devalued on October 18, 1998 by 2.97 percent. The Government has also announced a set of tax measures aimed at raising an additional Tk 3 billion in revenues. These include a temporary 4 percent surcharge on existing supplementary duties on luxury items; a surcharge on telephone, fax, telex and email fees; a surcharge on income from savings certificates and fixed deposits at banks and other financial institutions; and a tax on passport renewals and issuance. 2.11 The Government is also exploring ways to conserve resources from the Annual Development Program (ADP) and to redirect expenditures towards the repair of damaged infrastructure. Project-related expenditures totaling Tk 6 billion have been identified for reallocation, and further such reallocations are expected. The Government has also indicated that it will identify low-priority projects that can be delayed or dropped from the ADP. Furthermore, past experience shows that actual ADP implementation is well below the budgeted ADP target, and this is even more likely to be the case with pervasive flooding during the first quarter of 1998/99. Assuming that the Government will significantly reallocate ADP funds to finance non- food, flood-related imports and pay for a part of the repairs to infrastructure, this first set of fiscal adjustments would result in an ADP of Tk 129 billion, which would be Tk 5 billion short of the 1998/99 pre-flood, Budget target. This would nonetheless still represent a 14 percent nominal increase over the 1997/98 outcome of Tk 113 billion. 2.12 The Government expects to close the post-adjustment financing gap of about US$530 million on the balance of payments with additional assistance (Table 3). The post-adjustment forecast suggests that the current account deficit would rise to 2.9 percent of GDP from the 1.5 percent 1997/98 outcome, with the level of foreign exchange reserves held steady at US$1.7 billion (or about 2.2 months of a higher import bill as compared to 1997/98). The Government also expects that with these adjustment measures the budget deficit would be 4.7 percent of GDP in 1998/99 (see also Chart 1.C), a smaller increase from the 1997/98 outcome of 4.2 percent than otherwise anticipated. Foreign financing as a percentage of GDP would rise relative to domestic financing in 1998/99 as compared to the previous year, with domestic financing held flat as a percentage of GDP (Chart 1.D). It will be important to ensure that any residual fiscal gap is not financed through increased borrowing from the banking system, since this would crowd out private sector activities and undermine monetary stability. III. PROJECT DESCRIPTION A. Project Strategy and Context 3.1 The proposed Emergency Flood Recovery Project is consistent with the core importance of maintaining macroeconomic stability for the Bank Group's Country Assistance Strategy for Bangladesh. The proposed Project represents the first part of the three-part strategy the Bank has adopted to assist Bangladesh in responding to the floods. The strategy covers (1) emergency recovery assistance needed to finance imports; (2) reprogramming existing IDA projects and supplementing them as necessary to provide rapid and flexible assistance for the rehabilitation of physical infrastructure damaged by the floods; and (3) longer-term strengthening of institutional capacity for disaster preparedness and management.
 8 B. Project Objectives 3.2 The proposed Emergency Flood Recovery Project would assist Bangladesh in maintaining macroeconomic stability by financing critical imports of food grains, edible oil, fertilizer, seeds, agricultural equipment and inputs, cement and other construction materials, industrial machinery, spare parts and raw materials, and fuel. The project has been prepared in close consultation with the Ministry of Finance, which would be the executing agency. In keeping with the project's emergency nature, it is envisaged that the project would start in November 1 998 and would be completed by December 31, 1999, closing within six months thereafter. C. Project Components 3.3 The proposed Emergency Flood Recovery Project would provide quick-disbursing support to finance imports on a positive list of items (Attachment 1). The project would, inter alia, assist: (i) farmers to obtain adequate supplies of seeds, fertilizers, agricultural equipment and other inputs so as to be able to plant the next boro rice crop. Concerted efforts are necessary to ensure that the forthcoming wheat and boro harvests will be good; (ii) the import of additional food grains in order to maintain and augment national food grain stocks, which would otherwise be depleted with the partial loss of major rice crops, and could have severe inflationary consequences and negatively impact the health, nutrition, and morbidity status of the poor, particularly women and children. Edible oil imports would also assisted to ensure adequate stocks and price stability; (iii) manufacturers to import machinery, spare parts and other industrial raw materials. In particular, it will be critical to ensure that the ready-made garments industry, accounting for more than 60 percent of Bangladesh's exports, is able to rehabilitate its machinery and equipment and make up for lost time; and (iv) the import of cement and other construction materials and of fuel and petroleum products to rehabilitate assets and restore economic activity while mitigating pressure on the balance of payments. 3.4 The US$200 million size of the proposed Emergency Flood Recovery Project is based on the Government's request for emergency assistance, on an assessment of the adverse impact of the floods, and on the expected aid from other sources. Without additional bilateral and multilateral aid, the foreign financing gap due to lower exports and higher imports would be expected to reach about US$530 million (Table 3). The Government expects to cover this gap with disbursements from the proposed Credit, the IMF's emergency assistance, assistance from the ADB, and food and commodity aid commitments made by other multilateral and bilateral donors.
 9 IV. PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION A. Project Organization and Management 4.1 The Ministry of Finance would implement the proposed Project in close collaboration with Bangladesh Bank. The Ministry of Finance would open a US dollar Special Account in Bangladesh Bank for the Credit, which would finance 100 percent of the foreign exchange costs of imports on the positive list agreed with the Government. Bangladesh Bank would provide quarterly and annual audit reports prepared by a private, independent auditor to monitor the transparency and efficient operation of the Project. B. Implementation Arrangements 4.2 In keeping with the emergency nature of this proposed assistance, implementation arnangements have been kept simple. To ensure due diligence and sound governance in the use of IDA funds, the arrangements would also seek to: * ensure that credit proceeds are managed responsibly and only used to finance imports of items contained in the positive list; . ensure proper procedures, such as on procurement and accounting, and the complete documentation of transactions; * provide frequent management information using suitable monitoring and audit tools. 4.3 Bangladesh Bank would release foreign exchange for public sector imports after satisfying itself that the import transaction is eligible, i.e. (i) the item is on the positive list, and (ii) stipulated procurement procedures have been followed. Bangladesh Bank would release foreign exchange for private sector imports to commercial banks subject to similar eligibility criteria. All releases of foreign exchange to a commercial bank for private sector imports would be made against equivalent taka deposits by the commercial bank into the Government's counterpart fund account. C. Procurement 4.4 A positive list of items for import financing has been agreed with the Government (Attachment 1). Procurement would be limited to goods from countries that are eligible under the Bank's Procurement Guidelines (Guidelines. Procurement under IBRD Loan and IDA Credits of January 1995, revised January and August 1996, and revised September 1997) and are also participating countries under current IDA guidelines. No more than 50 percent of the Credit would be used in the aggregate for the import of any single item on the positive list. Public sector import contracts of less than US$50,000, and private sector import contracts of less than US$20,000 would not be eligible for financing under the Credit to avoid excessive overhead costs. 4.5 Commodities, such as food grains, fertilizer, and fuel, may be procured under the Project by both the public and private sectors through established international commodity markets, or through simplified procurement procedures in accordance with the Bank's Procurement Guidelines (Table 5). All contracts of US$5 million and above would be subject to the Bank's standard prior review procedures. All contracts below US$5 million would be subject to a post review by the Bank.

Disbursements would be made into the Special Account on the basis of fully documented withdrawal applications prepared by Bangladesh Bank. For contracts costing less than or equal to US$5 million, disbursements may be made on the basis of statements of expenditures. All supporting documents related to withdrawals on the basis of statements of expenditures would be retained by Bangladesh Bank for verification. This Credit is expected to disburse in about a year. The completion date would therefore be December 31, 1999, with six
 11 months thereafter for the finalization of accounts and submission of final withdrawal applications and other reports. 4.9 To facilitate the financing of items on the positive list that have already been imported as a result of the emergency, the Project would allow retroactive financing up to a ceiling of 20 percent of the Credit proceeds, or US$40 million. This would apply to eligible imports for which payments were made after July 12, 1998, the date of the onset of the floods. E. Accounts, Audits, and Internal Controls 4.10 Bangladesh Bank would provide adequate staff for managing the Project and maintaining proper accounts and records. The financial records should be kept in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles and practices. Prior to project start-up, Bangladesh Bank, with assistance from the Bank's financial management and procurement staff in Dhaka, would establish a suitable financial management system in compliance with the Bank's Operational Policy 10.02 on financial management. The system should facilitate the timely preparation and submission of accounts and provide reliable accounting data for managing and monitoring the project. Due to the short implementation period of about one year,in addition to the standard fiscal year-end audits by an independent, external auditor, the use of credit funds would be audited also on a quarterly basis. As a condition of effectiveness, Bangladesh Bank would appoint a qualified private firm as the independent auditor to conduct these audits on terms and conditions acceptable to the Bank. Internal controls for the Project would include the proper segregation of functional and financial responsibilities for approving the use of project funds. F. Reporting and Monitoring 4.11 To facilitate the quarterly and annual reviews, Bangladesh Bank would maintain all documentation with respect to the Credit and its disbursement. It would also be responsible for submitting quarterly reports to the Bank, via the Finance Ministry, that would cover: (a) Summary of Sources and Uses of Funds; (b) Procurement Management Report, and (c) the Quarterly Audit Report prepared by the independent auditor. Specific assistance, if required, would be made available from the Bank's Dhaka Office, which would maintain close liaison with Bangladesh Bank on all implementation matters. 4.12 Bank staff would monitor credit implementation and its macroeconomic impact in terms of indicators for the balance of payments, and other standard macroeconomic variables (Attachment 2). A post-completion review would focus on the value added of the Project in terms of sustaining macroeconomic stability and the continued achievement of project objectives.

doc.abstracts: The Emergency Flood Recovery Project will assist the Government in maintaining macroeconomic stability while helping to finance import costs associated with restoring infrastructure assets, production levels, and food grain stocks. This is the first part of International Development Association's three-part strategy to help Bangladesh respond to the 1998 floods. The project will provide assistance for: 1) the agricultural sector, to ensure that farmers have adequate supplies of seeds, fertilizers, and other agricultural inputs for planing the next boro rice crops; 2) additional food grain imports in order to maintain and augment food grain stocks that will otherwise be depleted with the partial loss of two rice crops; 3) the manufacturing sector, in order to enable manufacturers to import machinery, spare parts, and other raw materials; and 4) additional imports of fuel, cement, and other construction materials that are needed for relief operations and rehabilitation of physical infrastructure.
